Posts.Content: Thanks Chuck. My urologist is relatively young but kind of a hot shot. He does vasectomy reversals and the most inflatable penile prostheses (IPP) on the west coast. I am not sure how much experience he has with prostate cancer but he is in a large practice in Mountain View, California (home of Google) where standards of care are pretty high. He did say that if I had a positive biopsy with a score of six, he would favor just watching it closely. I understand the arguments in favor of active surveillance but don't think it is for me. The way I see it a score of six is actually AT LEAST six, with upgrades occurring in up to 50% of cases that proceed to prostatectomy. It is my understanding that you can't get in to see Dr. Peter Carroll at UCSF unless you already have a cancer diagnosis. I am unsure who to try to get to do the biopsy. The fact that I do have an IPP that Dr. Karpman did adds some additional factors to think about and lead me to lean toward letting him do the biopsy and take it from there.
Posts.Title: Sort of new here

Posts.Content: My next PSA is this Tuesday. No sex until after! Chico is a small city of 90K about 100 miles north of Sacramento and medical care is kind of primitive here. Anything serious entails the logistical challenges of travel to UC, Davis, UCSF, or Stanford. Fortunately, there is a new imaging center in town and they have a 3T MRI, the next closest one is at Stanford. If my PSA has not dropped to 2.0 or lower I am going to request a 3T MRI before proceeding and a PSAFT. I am calling UCSF tomorrow for further guidance as I remain unclear about the role that special expertise plays in performing a biopsy.

Posts.Title: Sort of new here

Posts.Content: Hello folks, I was here for a while a couple of years ago during what turned out to be a false alarm. My "handle" then was JDavid. This summer, my PSA went up from 1.6 to 3.7. DRE was negative for any lumps. Since I have fairly pronounced BPH, my urologist put me on Mobic for a couple of weeks and started me on FloMax. The plan is to re-do the PSA in a couple more weeks. If it has not gone down, or has increased, then it is biopsy time. At this point I am focused on if I need a biopsy I would like to do what I can to assure it is as accurate as possible. My hunch is that Dr. Karpman's plan is a standard twelve core biopsy done in the office. Any suggestions are most welcome. Dave
Posts.Title: Sort of new here

Posts.Content: My most immediate question is whether to begin trying to arrange for the biopsy at (if my PSA does not go down) or Let Dr. K do it and take it from there. I am fairly clear that that if I wind up with a G6 or more I will want to have an RP and would probably seek out Dr. Carroll. One of my worries is that in some clinical settings, once a physician sees you you essentially become that physician's patient, come what may. I don't think Dr. Carroll will do the biopsy and if another doc in the practice does it, that may mean Dr. Carroll refuses to treat me. I guess I need to call.

Posts.Title: Sort of new here

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael, Getting those additional diagnostic tests makes sense. I am not too averse to getting a biopsy but would like it to be as definitive as possible. Right now I am waiting for the date on my lab slip (9-20-16). Dr. K expressed doubts that this is cancer due to my previous low numbers and rapid rise. I have a history of repeated bouts of prostatitis that always responded to antibiotics if they were prescribed aggressively. He brought up that possibility but didn't want to "throw antibiotics" at it absent a UA that was positive for infection.

Posts.Title: Sort of new here

Posts.Content: As a twenty-five year lymie, I have to say that Lyme disease testing is lousy. It is a clinical diagnosis that can be SUPPORTED by positive serology. That said, long-term Lyme disease seems to rarely cause only pain. In my case I had hyperthyroidism, cognitive problems, night sweats, chronic recurrent respiratory problems to the point that one pulmonologist diagnosed me with COPD, vision problems, along with muscle and skeletal pain. It is typically a multi-system illness. On the other hand, I am glad that Lyme has been considered. Often, even in obvious cases, it is not. An ELISA test is worthless. A western blot is a bit better.
Posts.Title: Aches and Pains and Prostates

Posts.Title: Aches and Pains and Prostates

Posts.Content: Fortunately I am not in the club. There was a scare this past summer. During that time I resolved that, if diagnosed, I would get surgery even if my score was G6. This supports my decision-making process.
Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: I had an implant three years ago, due to chronic ED, not cancer surgery and it works perfectly. You might want to check out franktalk.org. It is an ED moderated website and has a forum on implants. Feel free to ask further questions.
Posts.Title: implant

Posts.Content: I suggest getting a second opinion, preferably with a recognized expert, before the biopsy. With a PSA drop, this may very well be an infection. My PSA shot up to 37 during a bout of prostatitis. Three weeks of antibiotics and six weeks to "cool down" it ws bact to 1.9.
Posts.Title: Confused and scared

Posts.Content: After recurring bouts of prostate problems a new urologist decided I had a chronic infection, despite no signs via urinalysis, and placed me on half a Bactrim per day, since january 2017. My PSA has gone from 3.7 to 2.6 to 1.9 to 1.7 a couple of month ago. I am thinking it is going to go lower and we will be able to establish an accurate baseline. You say antibiotics have not worked. Maybe they have not been the correct ones, maybe the dosage has been inadequate, maybe the duration has not been long enough.
Posts.Title: Just turned 38 and my prostate issues not going away is this indicative of PC?

Posts.Content: You might want to check out Emory University in Atlanta. I moved from Atlanta to the Tampa Bay area in 1990 and was immediately underwhelmed by the general quality of medical care in Florida.
Posts.Title: Need MRI Tampa? Miami? Orlando?

Posts.Content: Thank you Highlander and ASAdvocate. Ordering a PSA test in the context of prostatitis is probably not good medical practice. A P.A. at a walk-in clinic did it. It made my regular doctor mad but yielded an interesting bit of information. In fact, I have it right now: Pain, frequency, chills, fever, malaise. I have been on Levaquin 750 mg. for three days and have had two shots or Rocephin, 1 gram. Hopefully I am turning the corner. Oh, and my urinalysis was negative for bacteria.
Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Content: Thank you Highlander and ASAdvocate. Ordering a PSA test in the context of prostatitis is probably not good medical practice. A P.A. at a walk-in clinic did it. It made my regular doctor mad but yielded an interesting bit of information. In fact, I have it right now: Pain, frequency, chills, fever, malaise. Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Content: Prostatitis has pushed my PSA as high as 37. Six weeks and three weeks of Levaquin later it back under 2. There is an orthodoxy out there that absence of bacteria in the urine means absence of bacteria in the prostate. All I can say is that, in the course probably ten bouts of prostatitis over a span of twenty years, I have never had a positive urine culture and antibiotics have always worked. I think that there is a good chance that your father's PSA numbers may not be reflective of the extent of the cancer. I hope you and your father get good news.
Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Title: Starting off the new year with my father's new diagnosis :-(

Posts.Content: Reading about all you guys struggling with ED really pains me because it is so unnecessary. I struggled with ED due to unknown causes (although chronic Lyme Disease may have had something to do with it) since my early forties. I tried the pills and got mostly side effects. My testosterone was low and being on injectable testosterone helped for a number of years but eventually that became ineffective. My history of Dupuytren contractions was an absolute contra-indiction to injecting into my penis and pumps were not for me. So I got an implant at age sixty-three. The actual surgery took about twenty minutes. I stayed in the the hospital overnight for IV antibiotics and pain control and drove myself home over two hundred miles the next day. I now have an erection on demand that lasts as long as I want it to, every single time. My insurance paid for most of the cost. Both Medicare and the VA cover it. My only regret is not having done this many years earlier. Hopefully this thread will be an avenue for discussing this option that is not offered often enough, for reasons that I just do not understand. I am glad to answer questions and also suggest a website named frankalk.org. It is a moderated website dealing with ED.
Posts.Title: Inflatable Penile Prostheses (Implants)

Posts.Content: Rooster, As I mentioned, I drove home over 200 miles the day after surgery. Dr. Karpman had me come in a week later and taught me how to inflate AND deflate and urged me to do it frequently. He had me back two weeks after that and cleared me for intercourse and again urged me to inflate as much as I could stand it, as often as I could stand it, in order to maximize size. He had me semi-inflated for the first week so that was a bit awkward but I wasn't lying around on pain pills, at all. That said, surgeons' skills vary and I went to the top doc for this procedure on the west coast. I am totally satisfied with the outcome. In several ways it is better than new.
Posts.Title: Inflatable Penile Prostheses (Implants)

Posts.Content: Tybeeman, hopefully you will soon be back at 100%. That said, the surgery seems like a distant memory and having erections on demand is wonderful.
Posts.Title: Inflatable Penile Prostheses (Implants)

Posts.Content: Tybeeman, I have not had an RP as my ED preceded a PCa diagnosis. In fact, I m getting a PSA drawn today to see if it continues to be elevated, which I suspect it will be. Dave
Posts.Title: Inflatable Penile Prostheses (Implants)

Posts.Content: Frank Zappa died of prostate cancer at forty-seven. He probably would have been detectable at forty, by current technology. I have personally known of one case detected and successfully treated with surgery at thirty-five and another at thirty-eight.
Posts.Title: Early Detection/Ben Stiller

Posts.Content: JLH, It can be challenging to find physicians who are truly supportive of our need for competent, compassionate, and empathic care. This is more so the case for members of oppressed sexual minorities. Nevertheless, you cannot hide and in this life we have to fundamental choices, cope or not cope. That's it! I would like to point out that the two most dreaded outcomes of prostate removal, impotence and incontinence, are both surgically remediable, The former can be dealt with in the form of an inflatable penile prosthesis (implant). The latter can be deal with via the installation of a "sling." Both are relatively minor surgeries, especially compared to prostatectomy, and yield excellent results. In my opinion, you need to move forward in seeking an assessment of your prostate status. You might also want to check out franktalk.org, a moderated web site dealing with erectile dysfunction on which there are many post prostatectomy men who have had an inflatable penile prosthesis and who describe themselves as having the best sex of their lives. I will add that the site is very gay friendly.
